question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

user_prompts:
QUESTIONS: {'P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('542e902f-2706-47a2-a19d-3aa8e32f34e3'), title='Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('673e7f6e-2c27-4df9-b9ec-1484bc1814e8'), title='Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('5180fbae-df79-4c08-98bb-1b1b72382103'), title='Will Elon Musk make a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024?', body="This question will resolve YES if Elon Musk appears unexpectedly at a significant cryptocurrency-related event in 2024, regardless of the event's location or date.", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_and_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('d5db7ce5-727e-4b02-a94a-91754bd0858c'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk shows up as a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (taking place on July 25-27, 2024) and (2) Elon Musk makes a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024?', body="This question will resolve YES if (1) Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024, and (2) Elon Musk appears unexpectedly at a significant cryptocurrency-related event in 2024, regardless of the event's location or date.", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_or_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('158e6ab2-bbcc-49bd-a28a-ccaf047a1788'), title='Will either of the following occur: (a) Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024? (b) Will Elon Musk make a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024?', body="This market will resolve YES if either of the following happens: (a) Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024; or (b) Elon Musk appears unexpectedly at a significant cryptocurrency-related event in 2024, regardless of the event's location or date.", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=False), 'Q_and_not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('77102f5d-49db-453e-83d2-d31ad2bdd5bb'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk makes a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024 (2) Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body="This question will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Elon Musk appears unexpectedly at a significant cryptocurrency-related event in 2024, regardless of the event's location or date, and (2) Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q_given_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('ee9d84e4-57a3-4c71-be33-12139b30fddf'), title='Given Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024?', body="This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

This question will resolve YES if Elon Musk appears unexpectedly at a significant cryptocurrency-related event in 2024, regardless of the event's location or date. 

Resolution criteria: Resolves YES if Elon Musk appears unexpectedly at any significant cryptocurrency-related event in 2024, given that he has shown up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024.", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='conditional_binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None)}

GENERAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!
metadata.chain_of_thought:
RECEIVED

P: #Reasons P may or may not happen
not_P: #Reasons not_P may or may not happen
para_P: #Reasons para_P may or may not happen
Q: #Reasons Q may or may not happen
P_and_Q: #Reasons P_and_Q may or may not happen
P_or_Q: #Reasons P_or_Q may or may not happen
Q_and_not_P: #Reasons Q_and_not_P may or may not happen
Q_given_P: #Reasons Q_given_P may or may not happen

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.27 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.83 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.73 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.71 + 0.23 - 0.33 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73 + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.71 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.71 - 0.12 is FALSE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

0.73

RECEIVED

For the question of whether Elon Musk will show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (P), I will consider factors such as his past attendance at similar events, his interest in Bitcoin, and any announcements made regarding his participation. Given his prominence in the cryptocurrency community, I estimate a moderate probability of around 0.65 for P.

For not_P, which is the probability that he will not show up, it is simply the complement of P. Therefore, I estimate not_P to be 0.35.

The para_P question, which asks if there is a chance that Elon Musk will attend the conference, is closely related to P and should have a similar probability estimate. Thus, I would also assign it a probability of 0.65.

For Q, which asks whether Musk will make a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024, I would consider his history of surprise appearances and the general unpredictability of such events. I estimate this probability to be lower, around 0.40.

P_and_Q involves both P and Q occurring simultaneously. Given the independent nature of these events, I would calculate this as P * Q. Therefore, I estimate P_and_Q to be approximately 0.26 (0.65 * 0.40).

For P_or_Q, I will apply the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. This yields a probability of 0.65 + 0.40 - 0.26 = 0.79.

The question Q_and_not_P asks if Musk will make a surprise appearance while not showing up at Bitcoin Nashville. Given the probabilities, I would estimate this to be 0.15, as it requires Q to be true while P is false, which is a more constrained scenario.

Lastly, Q_given_P, which asks about the likelihood of a surprise appearance given that he shows up at Nashville, would likely be higher than Q alone because being present at Nashville could increase the chances of him making surprise appearances at other events. I would estimate this to be around 0.55.

In summary, I have considered the relationships between these questions, their independence, and how they interact with each other to arrive at these estimates.

P: 0.65,
not_P: 0.35,
para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.40,
P_and_Q: 0.26,
P_or_Q: 0.79,
Q_and_not_P: 0.15,
Q_given_P: 0.55

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.79 + 0.26 - 0.40 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.40 - 1, 0) <= 0.26 <= min(0.65, 0.40) is FALSE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.40) <= 0.79 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.40) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.79 - 0.15 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.26 / 0.55 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

neg, and, cond consistency checks failed!

Q: 0.40,
P_and_Q: 0.24,
P_or_Q: 0.76,
Q_and_not_P: 0.16,
Q_given_P: 0.50

0.6

question.title: Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

In this scenario, we are assessing the probability estimates for various events related to Elon Musk's appearances at cryptocurrency events in 2024, particularly focusing on the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 event. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This question is likely to have a moderate probability, as Musk has shown interest in cryptocurrency events before. However, the specific nature of his attendance is uncertain, leading to a probability estimate of around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This would be the complement of P. Given the estimate for P, the probability of not_P would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This question is similar to P and would likely have the same probability estimate of 0.60.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024)**: Considering Musk's unpredictable nature, the probability of him making a surprise appearance at any major event could be estimated at 0.50.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: The probability of both events occurring would be lower than either event happening independently. If we estimate P at 0.60 and Q at 0.50, we could estimate P_and_Q at around 0.30, since both events are not fully independent.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This would be calculated using the formula for the union of two events. Given estimates for P and Q, we might estimate P_or_Q at around 0.70.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs but not P)**: This event would likely have a lower probability, as it requires Musk to make a surprise appearance without attending the Nashville event. I would estimate this at 0.15.

8. **Q_given_P (Given P occurs, does Q also occur?)**: This conditional probability would depend on the likelihood of Musk making a surprise appearance given that he has already attended the Nashville event. I would estimate this at around 0.60.

In summary, these probabilities are interconnected, and adjustments to one will affect others due to the logical relationships defined by the consistency rules. For instance, if P is high, not_P must be low, and if P_and_Q is estimated, it must adhere to the maximum probability constraints set by P and Q.

P: 0.60,
not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.60,
Q: 0.50,
P_and_Q: 0.30,
P_or_Q: 0.70,
Q_and_not_P: 0.15,
Q_given_P: 0.60

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.60 = 1 - 0.40 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.60 = 0.70 + 0.30 - 0.50 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.60 + 0.50 - 1, 0) <= 0.30 <= min(0.60, 0.50) is FALSE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.60, 0.50) <= 0.70 <= min(1, 0.60 + 0.50) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.60 = 0.70 - 0.15 is FALSE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.60 ≈ 0.30 / 0.60 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.60 = 0.60 is TRUE

neg, and: consistency checks failed!

not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.60,

question.title: Will OpenAI publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

In this scenario, we are predicting the likelihood of Elon Musk attending specific events related to Bitcoin and cryptocurrency in 2024. The questions are interrelated, and the predictions must reflect the logical relationships between them.

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is specific, and given Musk's history with cryptocurrencies, I estimate a moderate probability of 0.65 that he will attend.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P, so it should be 1 - P, which would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially the same question as P, so I will assign it the same probability of 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024?)**: Given Musk's unpredictable nature, I estimate a probability of 0.50 for this event.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: The probability of both events occurring is likely lower than either event alone, so I estimate this at 0.30. This reflects the idea that while he might attend the Nashville event, it doesn't guarantee he will appear at another event unexpectedly.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This probability can be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Substituting the values, P_or_Q = 0.65 + 0.50 - 0.30 = 0.85.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P occur?)**: For this, I estimate a lower probability, given that if he surprises at another event, it doesn't necessarily mean he won't attend Nashville. I estimate this at 0.15.

8. **Q_given_P (Given P, will Q occur?)**: If he attends the Nashville event, it may increase the likelihood of him making a surprise appearance elsewhere. I estimate this probability at 0.60.

Overall, the predictions must adhere to the consistency rules. For example, the relationship between P and not_P must hold (P + not_P = 1), and the probabilities for P_and_Q and P_or_Q should reflect their definitions. I will ensure these relationships are maintained in my final probability estimates.

not_P: 0.35,
P_or_Q: 0.85,
Q: 0.50,
P_and_Q: 0.30,
Q_and_not_P: 0.15,
Q_given_P: 0.60,
para_P: 0.65

and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.50 - 1, 0) <= 0.30 <= min(0.65, 0.50) is FALSE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.50) <= 0.85 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.50) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.85 - 0.15 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.30 / 0.60 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

For the given questions regarding Elon Musk's potential appearances at cryptocurrency events in 2024, I will assess each event and their relationships to derive probability estimates. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: Given Musk's high-profile nature and previous engagements with cryptocurrency, I estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend this specific event. 

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This probability is complementary to P, so it will be lower than P. 

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is effectively the same as P, so I would expect it to have a similar value.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024)**: Given Musk's history of surprise appearances, I would assign a reasonable probability to this event, albeit lower than P since it encompasses any event in 2024.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This will be the product of the probabilities of P and Q, but adjusted for any correlation. If P and Q are independent, I can multiply their probabilities; otherwise, I will need to assess their joint likelihood.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This is calculated by the formula P + Q - P_and_Q, which takes into account the overlap between P and Q.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs and P does not)**: This situation requires careful consideration, as it is possible for Musk to make a surprise appearance elsewhere while not attending the Nashville event. Therefore, this probability should be derived from the estimates of Q and not_P.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given that P occurs)**: This conditional probability will depend on how likely Q is if we know that P is true. Since attending the Nashville event may increase the likelihood of making another appearance, this should be higher than the base rate of Q.

In terms of independence, P and Q are related but not completely independent. Musk's attendance at the Nashville conference may influence his likelihood of making other appearances, hence I will account for correlation where necessary. 

Overall, the estimates will need to be consistent with the rules provided, ensuring that complementary and conditional relationships are respected.
